questions.text: A patient with a persistent cough and fever undergoes diagnostic testing, revealing acid-fast bacilli in a sputum sample stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain. Which of the following characteristics of the bacteria contributes to its ability to retain the stain despite acid-alcohol decolourisation?

choices.text: Mycolic acids in the cell wall

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Mycolic acids in the cell wall

 

Explanation:

Mycolic acids are long-chain fatty acids found in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. They contribute to the hydrophobic nature of the cell wall, which retains stains like Ziehl-Neelsen despite acid-alcohol decolourisation.

 

Mode of transmission of TB

  • Spread via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals.
  • Other modes are:
    • Inoculation
    • Ingestion

 

Antigenic Structure

  • Cell wall antigens:
    • Peptidoglycan layer
    • Arabinogalactan layer
    • Mycolic acid layer: Principal constituent and is responsible for the acid fastness and also reduces the entry of most antibiotics
    • Outermost lipid layer
    • Protein layer
    • Lipoarabinomannan layer in the plasma membrane, which is used as a target antigen for TB diagnosis
  • Cytoplasmic antigens:
    • Antigen 5
    • Antigen 60

 

Cell wall of M. Tuberculosis

Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in the cell wall (Option A): LPS is typically found in gram-negative bacteria and is not a component of the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This option is incorrect.

Biofilm formation (Option C): Mycobacterium tuberculosis can form biofilms in certain conditions, but this characteristic does not directly contribute to its ability to retain acid-fast staining. This option is incorrect.

Capsular polysaccharides (Option D): Mycobacterium tuberculosis does not produce a capsule that would affect acid-fast staining. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a cough for 3 weeks, weight loss, fever, and blood in sputum. Chest X-ray reveals a small granuloma in the mid-lung region along with enlarged hilar lymph nodes. Which of the following terms best describes these findings in the context of primary pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Primary Complex

 

Explanation: In primary pulmonary tuberculosis, granuloma forms in the lung parenchyma known as a Ghon focus. The combination of this granuloma and the adjacent hilar lymph node involved without any calcification is referred to as a Ghon /primary complex

 

Clinical manifestations of Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

Pulmonary tuberculosis is most common in India.

Primary tuberculosis

Post-primary or secondary tuberculosis

Miliary tuberculosis (option D ruled out)
  • Initial infection by the bacteria in the host.
  • Ghon’s focus (option C ruled out): the subpleural focus of tuberculous pneumonia representing the initial site of infection and the primary response of the host.
  • Common location: lower lobe or the lower part of the upper lobe
  • primary complex (option B): Ghon’s focus together with the enlarged hilar lymph node.
  • Ranke complex (option A ruled out): Healed calcified nodules from primary infection.
  • Post-primary progression or reactivation of latent infection, or exogenous reinfection.
  • Common location: upper lobes of the lungs.
  • Lesions undergo necrosis and destruction of tissues leading to cavitation.
  • Lymph node involvement is uncommon.
  • It is caused in immunocompromised individuals where the bacteria in primary or secondary infection can spread causing dissemination to other organs.
  • Genitourinary tract
  • Lymph nodes (cervical lymphadenitis)
  • Central nervous system (meningitis)
  • Bone and joint (arthritis and osteomyelitis)
  • Peritoneum
  • Gastrointestinal system
  • Pericardium
  • Larynx
  • Pleural lining (pleuritis)

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic tests on sputum is most appropriate as an initial test for a case of suspected tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique

 

Explanation: Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is less expensive than NAAT and useful in rapid detection and determining infectiousness as the incidence of false-positive smears is very low with the maintenance of good quality control.

Diagnostic test

Key concepts

Microscopy (useful in rapid detection and determining infectiousness)

Ziehl-Neelsen technique (ZN) (hot stain procedure) (Option D)
  • Smears are dried, heat-fixed and stained
  • Carbol fuschin, sulphuric acid, methylene blue

Kinyoun acid-fast stain (cold stain procedure)

No heating.

Fluorochrome Stain
  • Smears are stained with auramine phenol or auramine rhodamine fluorescent dyes
  • Examined under ultraviolet illumination

Culture

Solid media
  • Löwenstein-Jensen media
  • Cultures are examined weekly for growth
  • Negative cultures (no growth) are reported, and the cultures are discarded only after 8 weeks of incubation

Liquid media
  • Middlebrook 7H9 broth, BACTEC 12B medium, MGIT, BacT Alert
  • Reduces the isolation turnaround time down to about ten days

Animal inoculation

Inoculated intramuscularly

Immunodiagnosis

Mantoux test (Option C ruled out)
  • Demonstration of hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein.
  • 0.1 ml of PPD containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally, induration of 10mm or more is positive.

Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRAs) (Option A ruled out)

Mycobacterium TB antigen CFP10 is used in the test, and it reacts with the patient's T cells to release γ interferons.

Molecular Tests

Genetic Sequencing and Nucleic Acid Amplification (Option B ruled out)
  • PCR amplification of mycobacterial DNA with genus-specific primers.
  • Xpert MTB/RIF (also detects the mutations associated with rifampin resistance)

 

DNA Microarrays

Quick analysis of many DNA sequences using just one hybridization step.

questions.text: A sputum sample from a patient suspected of having tuberculosis is cultured on Lowenstein-Jensen media. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of the colonies after 6 weeks of incubation?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Rough, buff-colored colonies

 

Explanation: Rough, buff (cream-coloured) and tough colonies on Lowenstein-Jensen media are characteristic of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Culture of M. tuberculosis

Solid medium

Löwenstein-Jensen media

 
  • 6-8 weeks to grow
  • Composition

Coagulated hen’s egg

Mineral salt solution

Asparagine

Malachite green

  • Morphology of colony: Rough, buff (cream-coloured) and tough. (option A)
  • Cultures are examined weekly for growth
  • Negative cultures (those showing no growth) are reported, and the cultures are discarded only after 8 weeks of incubation.

Tharshi medium

Blood-based culture

Loeffler’s medium

Serum-based culture

Pawlowsky medium

Potato-based

Liquid medium

Middlebrook’s medium

Contains 2% glycerol

Bactec MGIT
  • Newer automated method
  • Uses Middlebrook 7H9 broth

 

 

Golden-yellow colonies (option B): It is characteristic of staphylococcus aureus on nutrient agar. This option is incorrect.

 

Blue-green pigment (Pyocyanin) (option C): It is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This option is incorrect.

 

Matt-finely granular colonies (option D): It is characteristic of virulent strains of streptococcus pyogenes when grown in blood agar. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following devices uses the fluorometric technique to monitor microbial growth in culture bottles?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Bactec machine

 

Explanation: The Bactec machine uses the fluorometric technique, where the mycobacterial growth uses oxygen, leading to fluorescence.

 

Newer automated methods:

Bactec MGIT 960 (option B)
  • MGIT: Mycobacterial Growth Indicator Tube
  • Middlebrook 7h9 Broth is used
  • Principle:
    • In the presence of oxygen, fluorescence is quenched
    • Bacteria use oxygen while growing causing fluorescence
  • It can detect both Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and nontuberculous mycobacteria.
  • Incubation temperature: 37 °C

Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube (MGIT) samples in ultraviolet light. The emission of orange fluorescence indicates the presence of mycobacteria

Bac T/alert (option A ruled out)

Colorimetric detection of CO2 produced by growing bacteria.

Versatrek (option D ruled out)

Detects pressure changes in media due to gas production.

Middlebrook’s medium (option C): It is a liquid medium culture containing 2% glycerol. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory wants to implement an automated system for the detection of mycobacteria in clinical specimens. Which of the following is the primary detection method used by the BacT/ALERT system to identify bacterial growth?

choices.text: Detection of CO₂ production using colorimetric sensors
Detection of pressure changes due to gas production

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Detection of CO₂ production using colorimetric sensors

 

Explanation:

The BacT/ALERT system uses colorimetric sensors to detect CO₂ production from metabolizing bacteria. As bacteria grow and produce CO₂, the system senses a colour change, indicating bacterial presence and growth.

 

Newer automated methods

Bactec MGIT 960

  • MGIT: Mycobacterial Growth Indicator Tube
  • Middlebrook 7h9 Broth is used
  • Principle:
    • In the presence of oxygen, fluorescence is quenched
    • Bacteria use oxygen while growing causing fluorescence (Options A & D ruled out)
  • It can detect both Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and nontuberculous mycobacteria.
  • Incubation temperature: 37 °C

Bac T/alert

Colorimetric detection of CO2 produced by growing bacteria. (Option B)

Versatrek

Detects pressure changes in media due to gas production. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with a persistent cough with blood in sputum, fever, and weight loss. The chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the upper lobes. The clinician wants a rapid and reliable test for diagnosing. Which of the following statements about the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is correct?

choices.text: It can detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance within 2 hours
It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM)
It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing
It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples

questions.solution:
Answer: A) It can detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance within 2 hours

 

Explanation:

The GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is a rapid, cartridge-based, automated nucleic acid amplification test that can detect both M. tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance in approximately 2 hours making it particularly valuable in high-burden, resource-limited settings.

 

The GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay offers several advantages:

  • Rapid results: Provides results in about 2 hours
  • Simultaneous detection of M. tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance
  • High specificity: >99% specific for M. tuberculosis complex
  • Minimal biosafety requirements: Can be used outside of reference laboratories
  • Automated interpretation: Reduces operator-dependent errors


 

It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) (Option B): While the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is highly specific for the M. tuberculosis complex, it cannot differentiate between M. tuberculosis and other members of the complex, nor can it identify NTM. This option is incorrect.

 

It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing (Option C): One of the advantages of the GeneXpert system is that it allows for safe handling of specimens and can be used in lower biosafety level settings due to its closed-cartridge system. This option is incorrect.

 

It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (Option D): While the sensitivity of GeneXpert is higher in smear-positive samples, it still maintains good sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (60-80%), outperforming smear microscopy. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old healthcare worker is being screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) as part of an occupational health program. Which of the following tests is considered the most specific for diagnosing LTBI in a person who has received BCG vaccination?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test

 

Explanation:

QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test is an Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) that uses M. tuberculosis-specific antigens ESAT-6, CFP-10, and TB7.7 not present in BCG or most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making it more specific for LTBI diagnosis in BCG-vaccinated individuals.

 

Latent TB can be diagnosed by two tests:

  • Tuberculin test /Mantoux test
  • Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA)

 

Tuberculin test /Mantoux test

  • Antigen: Purified protein derivative (PPD)
  • Procedure:
  • 0.1 ml of PPD containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally
  • Examined after 48-72 hours
  • Interpretation:

Width of induration (measurement done perpendicular to the long axis of the forearm)

Inference

≥ 10mm

Positive

6-9mm

Equivocal

≤ 5mm

Negative
  • Equivocal is considered positive in:
    • HIV / Immunosupressed
    • Known close contact
    • H/o Prior TB

 

Note: Erythema is not taken into consideration for the interpretation of results.

  • Lower specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals due to cross-reactivity with antigens present in the BCG vaccine and can yield false-positive results (Option A ruled out)

 

Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA)

  • Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens.
  • IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis:
    • Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals)
    • No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria
    • Requires only a single patient visit
    • Results are available within 24-48 hours
    • No boosting effect with repeated testing
  • Disadvantage: Cannot differentiate between an active and inactive infection


 

BacT / ALERT (Option C): It is an automated blood culture system designed to detect M. tuberculosis in clinical samples containing viable bacteria. It is not used for detecting latent tuberculosis. This option is incorrect.

 

Chest X-ray (Option D): It is not a specific test for LTBI. It may show changes suggestive of past TB exposure or active TB, but cannot definitively diagnose LTBI in BCG vaccinated person. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 35-year-old is being screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). Which of the following statements about Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) is correct?

choices.text: IGRAs use PPD as the stimulating antigen
IGRAs can differentiate between LTBI and active TB
IGRAs measure interferon-gamma released by T cells in response to specific M. tuberculosis antigens
IGRAs can detect MPT64 antigen in patient samples

questions.solution:
Answer: C) IGRAs measure interferon-gamma released by T cells in response to specific M. tuberculosis antigens

 

Explanation:

IGRAs measure interferon-gamma released by T cells in response to specific M. tuberculosis antigens, providing a measure of the cell-mediated immune response to TB infection.

 

Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA)

  • Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens.
  • IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis:
    • Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals)
    • No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria
    • Requires only a single patient visit
    • Results are available within 24-48 hours
    • No boosting effect with repeated testing
  • Disadvantage: Cannot differentiate between an active and inactive infection

 

LAM assay:

  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is a cell wall component of M. tuberculosis
  • It can be detected in urine especially
  • It can be useful in diagnosing active TB in HIV-positive patients with low CD4 counts

 

MPT 64 patch test: (Option D ruled out)

  • Antigen: Patch containing purified MPT64 protein
  • Helps differentiate Mycobacterium.Tb from Atypical Mycobaterium
  • Procedure:
    • The patch is placed on the ventral surface of the forearm
    • The skin reaction is read after 4 days
  • Inference: Positive reaction: Erythema, induration or small red vesicles at the patch site


 

IGRAs use PPD as the stimulating antigen (Option A): IGRAs do not use PPD (Purified Protein Derivative) as the stimulating antigen. Instead, they use M. tuberculosis-specific antigens like ESAT-6 and CFP-10. This option is incorrect.

 

IGRAs can differentiate between LTBI and active TB (Option B): While IGRAs are excellent for detecting M. tuberculosis infection, they cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A newborn child in a high TB-burden country is being considered for BCG vaccination. Which of the following statements about the BCG vaccine is correct?

choices.text: It provides 100% protection against all forms of tuberculosis
It is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis
It is contraindicated in HIV-positive infants regardless of their immune status
It is most effective in preventing tuberculous meningitis in adults

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis

Explanation:

  • BCG vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis. It was first developed by Calmette and Guérin in 1921 through serial passages of a virulent M. bovis strain.

BCG Strains:

Different BCG strains are used worldwide, which may contribute to variations in vaccine efficacy.

Route of Administration:

  • Intradermally, usually in the left deltoid region
  • Correct technique is crucial for optimal immune response and minimizing adverse effects

Duration of Protection:

  • It is not well-defined and may wane over time.

It provides 100% protection against all forms of tuberculosis (Option A): The BCG vaccine does not provide complete protection against all forms of tuberculosis. Its efficacy varies widely (0-80%) depending on the form of TB and geographical location. It is most effective against severe forms of childhood TB, such as miliary TB and tuberculous meningitis. This option is incorrect.

It is contraindicated in HIV-positive infants regardless of their immune status (Option C): While caution is needed, BCG is not universally contraindicated in all HIV-positive infants. The decision depends on the infant's immune status and local TB prevalence. It is contraindicated in symptomatic HIV infection but may be given to asymptomatic HIV-positive infants in high TB-burden settings. This option is incorrect.

It is most effective in preventing tuberculous meningitis in adults (Option D): While BCG can provide some protection against tuberculous meningitis, it is most effective in preventing severe forms of TB in children, not adults. This option is incorrect.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left leg and hand. He gives a history of frequently swimming in a local pool. The ulcer grew in size gradually and developed into a chronic, painless granuloma as shown in the image. Which organism is most likely responsible for his condition?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Mycobacterium marinum

 

Explanation:

M. marinum is a photochromogen associated with "swimming pool granuloma," resulting from exposure to contaminated water. The chronic, painless ulcer described depicts the case of an M. marinum infection.

 

Non-tuberculous Mycobacteria (NTM)

  • Definition: NTM are diverse mycobacteria found in soil, water, and animals, primarily affecting those with weakened immune systems
  • Transmission: Not spread person-to-person; typically contracted from contaminated water or soil

Runyon Classification of NTM

Group

Characteristics

Examples

Group I: Photochromogens

Produce pigment in light; slow growth.

M. kansasii (lung disease), (Option A ruled out)

M. marinum ("swimming pool granuloma"). (Option B)

Group II: Scotochromogens

Produce pigment regardless of light; varied growth rates.

M. scrofulaceum (swollen lymph nodes),

M. gordonae (water contamination).

Group III: Non-photochromogens

No pigment production; diverse characteristics.

M. avium complex (lung infections), (Option C ruled out) M. ulcerans (Buruli ulcers).

Group IV: Rapid Growers

Grow quickly; early colony formation.

M. fortuitum (skin abscesses), (Option D ruled out)

M. chelonae (injection site infections).

Diagnosing Non-tuberculous Mycobacteria (NTM) Infections

  • Microscopy:
    • Acid-fast staining was used initially but was not conclusive for NTM diagnosis (shared with M. tuberculosis).
  • Culture:
    • Essential for definitive identification.
    • Various growth rates help classify NTM species:

 

NTM Group

Growth Characteristics

Rapid Growers

Form colonies within days (e.g., M.fortuitum).

Slow Growers

May take weeks to form colonies (e.g., M.kansasii).

Treatment:

  • Specific to species and drug susceptibility.
  • Includes prolonged multi-drug therapy.
  • Surgery may be necessary for localized cases.

questions.text: Which type of leprosy is most likely affecting a patient who presents with localized, well-defined skin lesions and minimal bacterial presence?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Tuberculoid leprosy

 

Explanation:

Tuberculoid leprosy is characterized by high host resistance, limited, well-defined skin lesions, and minimal bacterial presence.

Transmission of Mycobacterium leprae

  • Source of Infection:
    • Leprosy is solely a human disease.
    • Infected individuals are the only source.
  • Transmission Route:
    • The precise route is unclear.
    • Significant shedding of bacilli through nasal secretions.
    • Possible transmission through the respiratory tract or skin.

Classification of Leprosy

Madrid Classification:

Type

Characteristics

Lepromatous Leprosy

Low host resistance, abundant bacilli in lesions, widespread lesions, higher transmission likelihood (Option B ruled out).

Tuberculoid Leprosy

High resistance, limited well-defined skin lesions, minimal bacilli in the lesions (Option A).

Dimorphous (Borderline)

Characteristics of both lepromatous and tuberculoid forms, potential to shift between the two (Option C ruled out).

Indeterminate Leprosy

Early, unstable stage, may resolve spontaneously or progress to other forms (Option D ruled out).

 

Ridley-Jopling Classification:

Type

Characteristics

Tuberculoid (TT)

High resistance, localized lesions

Borderline Tuberculoid (BT)

Intermediate between TT and BB, some features of both

Borderline (BB)

Intermediate, with features of both tuberculoid and lepromatous forms

Borderline Lepromatous (BL)

Intermediate between BB and LL, some features of both

Lepromatous (LL)

Low resistance, disseminated disease


 

Category

Lepromatous Leprosy (LL)

Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT)

Bacillary Load

Multi-bacillary

Pauci-bacillary

Bacteriological Index

Higher load (4-6+)

Lower load (0-1+)

Skin Lesions

Leonine facies, Alopecia

Few lesions

Nerve Lesions

Late

Early

Cell-mediated Immunity

Low

Normal

Lepromin Test

Negative

Positive

CD4/CD8 Ratio

1:2

2:1

Humoral Immunity

Increased

Normal

Macrophages

Foamy type

Epithelioid type

Giant Cells

Negative

Present

 

This system provides a spectrum from TT (high resistance, localized lesions) to LL (low resistance, disseminated disease), characterizing the disease's progression.

 

Classification Based on Bacterial Load:

Classification

Characteristics

Associated Type

Clinical Features

Multibacillary Leprosy

High bacterial load, clusters of bacilli ("globi") in lesions

Lepromatous leprosy

Low host resistance, widespread lesions, higher transmission risk

Paucibacillary Leprosy

Minimal bacterial presence

Tuberculoid leprosy

High host resistance, limited skin lesions

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with 5 hypoesthetic skin lesions on his arms, legs, along with palpable thickening of the ulnar nerve. There are no visible nodules. Skin smears reveal a low bacterial index. Which treatment regimen is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Rifampicin and dapsone daily for 6 months
Rifampicin monthly, daily dapsone, and daily clofazimine for 6 months
Rifampicin monthly and daily dapsone for 6 months
Rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine for 12 months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rifampicin monthly, daily dapsone, and daily clofazimine for 6 months

Explanation:

The patient's presentation with 5 hypoesthetic skin lesions and 1 thickened nerve without nodules is consistent with a paucibacillary form of leprosy. For paucibacillary leprosy, the WHO recommends the following regimen:

  • Rifampicin: once a month
  • Dapsone: daily
  • Clofazimine: daily

Diagnosis of Mycobacterium leprae Infection (Leprosy):

  • Clinical Classification: Classified into multibacillary (MB) and paucibacillary (PB) forms based on bacterial load.
  • Diagnostic Methods:
    • Microscopy: Mainstay for detecting acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in nasal and skin smears by Ziehl-Neelsen staining.
      1. Nasal smears target shed bacilli; skin smears from lesion edges.
      2. Slit-skin smear enhances bacillus detection from small cuts.
    • Grading Systems: Quantify bacilli to determine bacterial index (BI)
    • Histopathology: Nodule or thickened nerve biopsy
    • Culture: Mouse footpad or armadillo inoculation.
    • Serological Tests and Molecular Methods.

Treatment of Mycobacterium leprae Infection (Leprosy):

Age group

Drug

Duration

Adult

Rifampicin - 600mg/month

+

Clofazimine - 300mg once a month & 50mg daily

+

Dapsone - 100mg daily

Multibacillary - 12 months

Paucibacillary - 6 months

Children

(10-14 years)

Rifampicin - 450mg/month

+

Clofazimine - 150mg once a month & 50mg on alternate days

+

Dapsone - 50mg daily

Multibacillary - 12 months

Paucibacillary - 6 months

 

Follow-Up
  • Paucibacillary: 4 years
  • Multibacillary: 8 years

Research
  • Immunotherapeutic vaccines (Mycobacterium W), alongside MDT, are being explored.

questions.text: A patient with chronic leprosy develops sudden onset of red, swollen, and tender lesions on existing skin patches. Which of the following reactions is most likely occurring in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Type 2 Reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL)

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of sudden onset red, swollen, and tender lesions in a patient with chronic leprosy is characteristic of Type 2 Reaction, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL).
  • ENL is an inflammatory response triggered by antigens released from dead M. leprae cells, leading to neutrophil infiltration and the formation of tender subcutaneous nodules. This reaction typically occurs in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous cases, often a few months into chemotherapy.

Character

Lepra Reaction Type I

Lepra Reaction Type II

Hypersensitivity

Type IV (Delayed Hypersensitivity)

Type III (Immune Complex-Mediated)

Seen with

Borderline leprosy (BL), Lepromatous leprosy (LL)

Lepromatous variety (LL)

Manifests as

Inflammation of previous lesions, new skin lesions, and neuritis

Crops of painful erythematous papules which become nodular, called ENL (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Progresses as

If it occurs before treatment, progresses towards LL (down-grading reaction)

If it occurs after treatment, it progresses towards TT (reversal reaction)

Usually occurs following the start of chemotherapy

T-helper Response

TH1 predominates, leading to increased IFN-γ and IL-2

TH2 predominates, leading to increased IL-6 and IL-8. TNF-α plays a central role

Other organs affected

Usually not affected

Eyes, testes, and kidneys are affected

Treatment

Glucocorticoid

Glucocorticoid, thalidomide, clofazimine, and antipyretics

 

Lepromatous Transformation (Option C): It doesn’t refer to a sudden reaction but rather to a shift toward the lepromatous end of the leprosy spectrum. It is characterized by a gradual increase in bacterial load and spread of lesions, rather than the acute onset of tender lesions. This option is incorrect.

 

Tuberculoid Transformation (Option D): It doesn’t indicate an acute reaction. It refers to a shift toward the tuberculoid form, usually indicating an improved immune response. However, such transformation does not cause acute inflammation or red, tender lesions as seen in the patient. This option is incorrect.
